Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Polymeric Nanostructures for Delivering Drugs and Imaging Agents
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Molecular biology has yielded a wealth of therapeutic molecules with potential to treat diseases and correct genetic defects, provided delivery and release issues can be resolved. Moreover, complexes of polymers with imaging agents have potential for unraveling structure-image relationships that may enable sufficient contrast to non-invasively monitor biodistribution of co-encapsulated drugs. This REU will focus on SYNTHESIS of well-defined polymers for delivering drugs and imaging agents, the ENGINEERING that characterizes assembly, structure and properties of polymer-drug-imaging agents, and the PHYSICAL SCIENCE that defines relationships among structure, release rates and mechanisms, and image sensitivity and contrast. This REU, funded by the Division of Materials Research of the NSF, will provide opportunities for 8 undergraduates to conduct 11 weeks of research on macromolecular drug and imaging agent complexes. The program is designed to instill in students a life-long motivation to create new materials and discover physical phenomena through the joys of research. Focus will be on science and engineering with added emphasis on building leadership, interdisciplinary teamwork and communications skills, and experiencing the gratification derived from integrating their science into the community. Particular focus will be on technical writing. The program includes a leadership workshop for the graduate student mentors, a community-building retreat with an ethics workshop, a short course on Principles of Polymeric Materials in Medicine and Biology, communications seminars and development of REU leadership skills through mentoring K-12 students in our Youth Experiencing Science (YES) program. At least 50% of our REUs will be women or minorities to ensure that they learn to work with a diverse group to prepare them for professional careers. The students will have opportunities to present their findings at a conference during the follow-up year.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Over the past about two decades, biologists and chemists have discovered a myriad of drugs that include small molecules and also larger therapeutic proteins and nucleic acids (i.e., DNA/RNA). Polymeric materials are needed to form complexes with many of these new drugs to improve their delivery to the necessary sites in the body. Such complexes can potentially offer sustained controlled release over long times, lower toxicities due to lower doses required, and protection against degradation through attack by physiological components such as enzymes or the immune system. Thus, this REU will focus on preparing well-defined polymers for delivering drugs and imaging agents, methods to assemble them into the required complexes with the drugs, and investigations of the physical principles that define relationships among their structure, release rates, and image sensitivity in the cases of delivering new bioimaging agents. The program, funded by the Division of Materials Research of the NSF, will provide opportunities for 8 undergraduates to conduct 11 weeks of research on drug and imaging agent complexes. The program is designed to instill in students a life-long motivation to create new materials and discover physical phenomena through the joys of research. Focus will also emphasize leadership principles, building interdisciplinary teamwork and communications skills that include technical writing, and learning to integrate their science into the community through mentoring K-12 students in our Youth Experiencing Science (YES) program. At least 50% of our REUs will be women or minorities to ensure that they learn to work with a diverse group to prepare them for professional careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DMR 1263248: Polymeric Nanostructures for Delivering Drugs and Imaging Agents, Judy Riffle, PI, Macromolecules and Interfaces Inst, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, VA 24061

 

Summary: The National Science Foundation Summer Undergraduate Research Site at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, VA focused on the design and discovery of Polymeric Nanostructures for Delivering Drugs and Imaging Agents. Thirty-seven outstanding U.S. undergraduates were funded by this grant for an intensive summer research experience. The primary summers included 2013-2015 with three additional students participating during the summer of 2016. The students worked under the direction of Professor Judy Riffle and with the coordination of Professor Maggie Bump. REU undergraduates participated from colleges and universities throughout the U.S. The administrative unit for the program was our Macromolecules and Interfaces Institute, which is an interdisciplinary, interdepartmental research and teaching institute at Virginia Tech focused on fundamental and applied research on polymeric materials. The participating (mentoring) faculty represented the Departments of Chemistry, Sustainable Biomaterials, Chemical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Biomedical Engineering.

Broader Impacts: This REU site program included several important out-of-laboratory elements in addition to the rigorous summer research experience including safety training, an introductory short course on polymer science and engineering, a one-day team-building exercise, discussions of scientific ethics, a workshop on technical communications focused on writing manuscripts and proper recording of data, intellectual property discussions, mentored creation of resumes and discussions of potential career paths, oral presentation skills, and a K-12 outreach program where the REU students mentored the K-12 students. Each summer culminated in a symposium where each of the REU students presented oral lectures describing their summer research that was attended by faculty, students and sometimes also family. Additionally, the K-12 “Say YES to Science” students presented their science demonstrations at the annual Steppin’ Out Blacksburg Street festival on our downtown center stage.

Intellectual Merit: Some of the technical highlights of the summer research included

  1. Design and Isolation of Cargo-Carrying Bacteria for Cancer Therapy. Matthew T. Long (University of Virginia), Eric Leaman, Chris Suh, Bahareh Behkam
  2. Time-Resolving Unimer Exchange in Block Copolymer Micelles. Katherine M. Miller (Stockton University), Bryce E. Kidd, Xiuli Li, J. Tyler, J. Cooksey, Megan L. Robertson, Louis A. Madsen
  3. Synthesis of Acrylamide Phosphonate Monomers and Polymers for Binding Bioimaging Agents and Inorganic Drugs. Ashley Peralta (Hampton University), N. Hu, J. S. Riffle
  4. Structure-Property Relationships of Segmented Phosphonium Ionenes for Treating Genetic Diseases. Zachary N. Weinrich (Case Western Reserve University), Sean T. Hemp, Timothy E. Long
  5. Facile Synthesis of Novel S-benzoyl Thiooximes for H2S Delivery. Chad Powell (Clemson University), J. Foster, J. Matson
  6. Adsorption of Immunoglobulin on Cellulose and Chitin Films Using Surface Plasmon Resonance. Nels T. Anderson (Northwest Missouri State University), Jinzhao Liu, Alan R. Esker
  7. Negative Isolation of Monocytes from Mouse Whole Blood via a Polydimethylsiloxane Microfluidic Device. Dylan Turpeinen (Michigan Technological University), Travis Murphy, Chang Lu
  8. Design and Fabrication of Chitosan Nanoparticles for Delivery of Rosmarinic Acid. Thomas Cotey (Case Western Reserve University), Ami Jo, Richey Davis
  9. Breast Cancer Single-Cell Motility and Contractile Force Measurements on STEP Suspended Fibers. Geoffrey Vaartstra (Syracuse University), Puja Sharma, Amrinder Nain
